In situ synthesis of nano-ZnO onto 100% cotton fabrics (terry or woven) by spraying or dipping process resulted in durable antibacterial and UV protection finishes. The nano-sized pore structure of cellulosic fibrils acted as nucleation site for formation of nano-ZnO from the precursors, zinc nitrate and sodium hydroxide. Both the processes resulted in excellent antibacterial activity (>98%) against two representative pathogens, Staphylococcus aureus (Gram-positive) and Klebsiella pneumoniae (Gram-negative) even after 50 wash cycles. The UV protection factor (UPF) was maintained above the minimum accepted level

. Introduction
Nano-ZnO revolutionized numerous sectors due to its novel echanical, electrical, optical, magnetic and chemical properties 1]. It forms a major ingredient of fabrics like cotton, nylon and olyester to impart functionalities [2]. The major challenge in using ano-ZnO on cotton fabrics is durable fixation as there is no affinty among them. Surface fixation using binder could not sustain the equired functionalities beyond 25 wash cycles [3]. In situ synthesis f nano-ZnO, a viable alternative method of application, produces otton fabric with durable self-cleaning activity [4] and antibacerial activity against Staphylococcus aureus and Escherichia coli [5]. nother green facile approach uses ashes of S. rosmarinus for simulaneous activation of cellulosic chains in cotton fabric and synthesis f nano-ZnO leading to self-cleaning and antibacterial activities, mproved crease recovery angle and tensile strength [6]. A longun experiment on 2500 m of fabric coated sonochemically with ano-ZnO in a hospital environment indicates reduced occurrence f hospital-acquired infections [7].
A recent review presents diverse aspects of nano-ZnO appliation in textile industries and approaches used for in situ nd ex situ syntheses to create diversified functionalities [8].

Cross-linking of nano-ZnO onto cotton fabrics using poly carboxylic acids [9], grafting of cotton with nano-ZnO using glycidyl methacrylate/acrylic acid [10] and plasma pre-treatment of cotton fabrics followed by pad-dry-cure application of nano-ZnO [11] are recently being attempted to improve the durability of functional finish. Most presented methods for stabilization of nano-ZnO on textile surfaces need several preparatory steps including functionalization, neutralization, washing, drying, curing, final treatment and other processing. In our earlier work [3], nano-ZnO stabilized by soluble starch was applied on cotton fabrics using an acrylic binder exhibited functional properties up to 25 wash cycles. In this work, we demonstrated the use of internal pore structure of cellulose as a nucleation site for in situ synthesis of nano-ZnO through simple protocols using sodium hydroxide and zinc nitrate with durable antibacterial and UV protection properties for 50 wash cycles.
2. Experimental
Terry fabric made of 100% cotton was used as substrate. The terry fabrics were woven using cotton yarns with the construction of open-end Ne 20/2 pile warp, open-end Ne 24/2 ground warp and open-end Ne 16/1 weft yarn. The thread density was 16 cm−1 and reed density was 12 cm−1. The sample size of 30 cm × 30 cm and six replicates was used for each set of experiment. The sequence of steps involved in two different processes (spraying and dipping) are given in graphical abstract. For spraying, the cotton fabric was

3. Results and discussion
In situ synthesis of nano-ZnO in cotton fabrics has been achieved by spraying and dipping processes. Ultrafine pores available on primary walls of cotton fibers were targeted as nucleating site for in situ synthesis of nano-ZnO. In spraying process, sodium hydroxide swells and fills the pores and subsequent spraying of zinc nitrate forms zinc hydroxide. While drying, ZnO is formed and its size was restricted by the size of pores. In dipping process, nitrate anions and zinc cations interact with the cellulosic chain, loosen the hydrogen bonds and ultimately increase the pore size by swelling. The reaction begins in the pores to form zinc hydroxide while immersed in sodium hydroxide. During drying, cellulose molecules get relived from the strain and retain their original positions, resulting in physical entrapment of ZnO inside the pores. In spray process, the reverse sequence of application could not be evaluated due to operational hazard in spraying sodium hydroxide. In dipping process, the reverse sequence resulted in more amount of zinc hydroxide bleeding from treated fabrics in the second step’s zinc nitrate bath. The Eqs. While bio-templates like folic acid nd starch were tried earlier to improve the in situ synthesis f nanoparticles of metal oxides and their stability [12], in this eported process, stability was ensured by physical entrapment of ano-ZnO in cellulose.
The fibrillar structure of control cotton fabrics could be visualzed in AFM height image given in Fig. 2a and its corresponding hase image does not show any prominent feature since there is nly one phase comprising of cellulose. In case of fabrics deposited ith nano-ZnO by spray process, the particles protruding from urface could be visualized in height image (Fig. 2b) while its coresponding phase image could differentiate them due to difference n hardness between ZnO and cellulose. Similar features could be een in dip-processed fabrics (Fig. 2c), but with more amount of nO. Also, the size of surface deposited ZnO particles were in the ange of 100–500 nm while those embedded inside the fibers were elow 100 nm as analysed using an Image analysis software.
In thermal analysis by DSC, an endothermic peak at 110 ◦C in ontrol and spraying processed cotton fabrics with small enthalpy hange was observed due to heat of evaporation of water molecules Fig. 3). Another endothermic peak at 362 ◦C in spray processed coton fabric and at 379 ◦C in control cotton fabric with larger enthalpy hange is attributed to thermolytic degradation of cellulose due to

cleavage of glycosidic bond and formation of flammable gases like pyroglucosan and levoglucosan. However in case of dip processed cotton fabric, instead of an endothermic peak, a small exothermic peak arose at 372 ◦C due to crystallization of ZnO. The heat required for thermolytic degradation of cotton was compensated with the heat evolved during crystallization process of ZnO and caused the disappearance of endothermic peak. The major peaks in the FTIR spectra of fabric (Fig. 3—inset) were corroborated with that of cellulose. A small peak at 440 cm−1 in case of treated fabrics corresponds to Zn O stretching frequency and its low intensity is due to restricted vibration of Zn O bond due to its entrapment inside the pores of cotton.
The dipping process resulted in 800 + UPF and spraying, 600 + UPF (Table 1) far exceeding commercial requirement of 50 + UPF for an UV protective textile. Even after 50 wash cycles, both the fabrics met the minimum requirement of an UV protective textile. The control cotton fabric’s UPF was less than 70. Nano-ZnO treated fabrics displayed more than 98% inhibition against both the pathogens, Staphylococcus aureus and Klebsiella pneumonia up to 50 wash cycles. The representative images showing the reduction in number of colonies of these two pathogens after 24 h of contact with spray processed cotton fabrics washed up to 50 wash cycles are given in Fig. 4. In an earlier work, a homogeneous distribution of nano-ZnO, 0 nm in size, was synthesized on the fabric surface by ultrasoundssisted coating having antibacterial activities against Escherichia oli (Gram negative) and Staphylococcus aureus (Gram positive) ultures at a concentration level of 0.75% coated fabric (wt.%) 16]. But, the durability of the treatment was not evaluated and he use of ultra-sound coating process is not easily scalable. This ork avoided the need of tedious protocols for in-situ preparaion of nano-ZnO, requirement of adhesives during coating, and volved simple/scalable protocols for in situ synthesis of nano-ZnO y spraying/dipping process resulting in durable (50 wash cycles) ntibacterial and UPF protection properties.
. Conclusions
This work focused on durable finishing of cotton fabrics using ano-ZnO, synthesized directly in cellulosic pores of cotton fabics by reacting zinc nitrate and sodium hydroxide. Spraying and ipping processes were optimized for in situ synthesis of nanonO to impart excellent antibacterial (>98% against two pathogens, taphylococcus aureus and Klebsiella pneumoniae) and UV protecion (50 + UPF) functionalities with a durability for 50 wash cycles. odium hydroxide swells the cellulose fibers and also oxidise zinc itrate to zinc oxide inside the swollen (microporous) structure f cellulose. These processes eliminate the need for binder to fix ano-ZnO and are easily scable in textile industries.
